content:
‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A well-defined and original problem with the right amount of complexity to make it an interesting clash, while still well-solvable in 5 minutes.

I'm happy to approve this mostly, but my only complaints are that for such a simple clash the statement is very long and the number of test cases is huge, beyond anything I've ever seen on a clash. :P

I don't really see the need for so many test cases, I can't imagine anyone really writing a solution for this that passes 20/38 of these... it seems to me that if your code can solve the ones with only two terms, then it can solve them all.

My hesitation is just that in Fastest mode, having long statements means that clashers who are less fluent in English will be disadvantaged and sometimes might even just quit when they see the long statement. Then for both Fastest and Reverse mode, having lots of test cases means that you are forced to choose whether to submit early and not bother checking if all of the tests pass, or wait for them all and potentially get beaten by someone who was willing to take the risk. :P

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: an easy level that requires a bit of logic, I approve.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is OK

It‚Äôs kind of similar to this, but maybe it‚Äôs ok?
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/180339fc604cea15b81d57790fa82265b48ac

Goal
* [[Difference]]: Please change ‚Äúeach integers‚Äù to ‚Äúconsecutive integers‚Äù.

* Please change ‚Äúnegative decrease‚Äù to ‚Äúnegative change‚Äù or ‚Äúnegative difference‚Äù (negative decrease = increase).

* Please change ‚Äúeach integer‚Äù to ‚Äúconsecutive integers‚Äù.

* ‚Äúwhere there are non-numerical, "+" or "-" characters in it.‚Äù: Actually negative signs do appear in the cases. Please revise your wording.

* Example 2: The sequence should be ‚Äú9 8 7 6 5‚Äù instead of ‚Äú98765‚Äù.

Output
* Please format ‚ÄúDirection‚Äù and ‚ÄúDifference‚Äù as [[variables]] instead of {{constants}}.

Constraints
* Please add [[difference]] ‚â† 0.

Cases
* Please change the sequences in Test 6 and Validator 6 to start from negative numbers which gradually increase to positive numbers.

* Validator 11: Please revise the case so that the sequence contains negative numbers only and decreasing at a rate of 10 or more.

* Test 12 and Validator 12: Please revise the cases so that the sequences contain negative numbers only, except for the last term which is 0, and increasing at a rate of 100 or more.

Thanks.

Thanks for commenting!

I have read through and fixed all the errors you raised.

Thanks for the reference to another similar clash. I would argue that while both deal with "Arithmetic Sequences", the other one is slightly more difficult... and mine is different because I don't deal with "Geometric Sequences". So, I think that mine should be ok with the community.

Once again, thanks for commenting.
Eh... Thanks.
Thank you, @Mathmo!

Hello @StepBack13, thanks for your concerns.

For your first point: I have changed the number of Test-cases and Validators to 12.

For your second point: I think that people can ignore the example if they'd wish to. I have removed fastest mode and reverse mode from this contribution.

Is that all? Did I miss any points?

Thanks again,
Code-Parser

@StepBack13, thank you very much.

I'm glad you think it is interesting. :)

Nice, I don't think you need to remove those modes. It's just a bit of a long statement, but I don't think that's any reason to disable Fastest mode. Especially since, as you mention, half of the statement is a detailed example which is fine to skim.

As for Reverse, this is a great clash for Reverse, since the long statement won't matter and now you've reduced the number of test cases so my other issue is null.

Re-activate those modes, and I'll approve. :)
I see... I'll see if I can shorten the description, while still maintaining it's clarity.

If you want to shorten, I think the bits about:
3 - 2 = 1 (The difference is +1)
4 - 3 = 1 (The difference is +1)
5 - 4 = 1 (The difference is +1)
6 - 5 = ... (This pattern continues throughout the sequence.)

Are a bit redundant, and won't work for 2-term series either. So just:
3 - 2 = 1 (The difference is +1)
would suffice.

You could also remove:
"Here is an example:"
Hmm... thanks, one minute.

Ok. Fixed it.

Thanks.

The changes are fine, but I'm still worried about the similarity. I have an idea: [[direction]] will still remain, but instead of [[difference]], the player has to extend the existing sequence by 1 term both ways and output the first term and the last term of the extended sequence. For example,

Input: 2 3 4 5
Output: Increasing 1 6

Input: 5 4 3 2
Output: Decreasing 6 1

What do you think?

Hmm... that is a good idea!

This would make it so that the coder would calculate the [[difference]], but instead of outputting the [[difference]]... they would take the first and last term of [[sequence]] and output the new first and last term? (Self-explanatory question!)

I will work on it.
Yup, you got it. The new idea extends your original one a bit - let the players take part in the sequence creation too!
I have fixed it! Please feel free to inspect the new variation.

Wow. I didn‚Äôt expect you to rewrite all the cases. I was expecting that you revised the output only. You‚Äôve put a lot of effort on it üëçüèª

Goal
* Please fix all the variable names to be consistent:

  - ‚Äúlast term‚Äù should be ‚Äúnext term‚Äù.

  - consistency in either using or not using an underscore in all the variable names for ‚Äúprevious term‚Äù and ‚Äúnext term‚Äù.

* Example: I‚Äôm not sure if the calculation of 1 and 10 should be shown. Do you think it‚Äôs ok to just state:
Moving backward from 2 and 3, the previous term is <<1>> ([[previous_term]]).
Moving forward from 8 and 9, the next term is <<10>> ([[next_term]]).

Cases
* Test 7: Please revise the input sequence to contain 2 terms only, similar to Validator 7.

* Test 14: Please revise the input sequence to contain 2 terms only, similar to Validator 14.

(By the way, 13 and 15 were skipped in the numbering of validators? Just asking; you‚Äôre free to use an arithmetic sequence to number the validators or not ü§ì)

* Validator 18: Please revise the case so that the previous term is negative and the next term is positive.

* Please add a pair of cases where the previous term is negative and the next term is 0.

Thanks.

P.S. Everybody who plays this clash will think I‚Äôm a negative person‚Ä¶

Fixed!

P.S. Removed your name from the Test-Case!

Cases
* Test 9 and Validator 9: Please change the cases so that for both cases, the **output** is ‚ÄúIncreasing‚Äù, a negative number and 0.

* Test 14: In the title of the name, please change ‚Äúto‚Äù to ‚Äútoo‚Äù. And thank you for removing me name. ü•∞

Thanks.

Fixed! And no problem!

Anything else to fix? Or should I go public for approval?
I don't see anything else to fix for now, thanks üôè
If it's alright... could you upvote this contribution? If not, that's fine. Thanks!
Done.
